review.title: Polymetric Rhythmic Feel for a Cognitive Drum Computer
review.abstract: This paper addresses a question about music cognition: how do we derive polymetric structures. A preference rule system is presented which is implemented into a drum computer. The preference rule system allows inferring local polymetric structures, like two-over-three and three-over-two. By analyzing the micro-timing of West African percussion music a timing pattern consisting of six pulses was discovered. It integrates binary and ternary rhythmic feels. The presented drum computer integrates the discovered superimposed polymetric swing (timing and velocity) appropriate to the rhythmic sequence the user inputs. For binary sequences, the amount of binary swing is increased and for ternary sequences, the ternary swing is increased.

metadata.title: Polymetric Rhythmic Feel for a Cognitive Drum Computer

sections.text: This paper addresses a question of music cognition: How do we derive polymetric structures? It introduces a preference control system implemented in a drum computer that allows the inference of local polymetric structures such as two over three and three over two. By analyzing the micro-timing of West African drum music, a timing pattern consisting of six pulses was discovered. It integrates binary and ternary rhythmic feelings. The drum computer introduced integrates the discovered superimposed polymetric swing (timing and velocity) according to the rhythmic sequence entered by the user. Binary sequences increase the amount of binary oscillation and ternary sequences increase the ternary swing.

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: Traditionally, it is the task of a human interpreter to add an artistic interpretation to bring the composition to life and make it sound. An interpreter adds "feeling," expression, articulation, phrasing or swing. If we describe the composer as the sender, the musical interpreter as the transmitter and the recipient as the recipient, a lack of expressiveness arises when the interpreter is absent. A composition based on simple, common notation, which is played rigidly and mechanically just like written notes. The aim of the current work is to model the artistic expression and cognitive processes of a human musician in order to obtain a living interpretation through the computer. A second goal is to gain a deeper knowledge of polyrhythmic music and timing structures.

sections.heading: 1.1 Music Analysis
sections.text: The rhythmic analysis approach is based on an adapted model of David Temperley's Preference System for Cognition of Fundamental Musical Structures [Temperl01]. In addition to the Temperley model, which derives a global meter, this approach identifies local polymetric structures for each rhythmic instrument in a musical ensemble, which can be the result of temporary ternary sequences in a global double meter (three over two) or binary sequences in a ternary meter (two over three).

sections.heading: 2.2 Timing Measurements
sections.text: To confirm the hypothesis that the micro-timing could be an overlapping binary / ternary swing, I focused on the analysis of polymetric West African percussion music of the Malinke from Guinea and the southern regions of Mali, in particular recorded djembé performances by drummer Billy Nankouma Konaté and his father Famoudou Konaté. 900 bars were measured, and the empirically observed timing structures were determined by measuring time spans between the intervals of successive drum beats. Measurements of each bar were normalized to a reference duration of one bar to compare timing patterns at different tempi.

sections.heading: 3.2 Phrase Structure
sections.text: In music perception, we group several similar sound events into phrases. Here, a simple approach is used to group sound events: (Gap Rule) According to Tenney et al. [Tenney80], we prefer gaps as phrase boundaries (closure) when the gap is greater than the gaps on both sides, especially those where the ratio of the gap to the previous one is greater. In addition, the following rule of preference is given: (Signature Rule) We prefer phrases where local metric structures are modulated. This means that there is a tendency to group sound events that are located within the same local meter.

sections.heading: 4 Musical interpretation based on the recognized musical structure
sections.text: The musical performance of the drum computer is based on the derived metric structure and the derived phrase structure. Therefore, a list of good interpretations (high score according to the preference rules) is considered. As the rhythmic sequence is played, the currently selected interpretation is switched from time to time to create a lively interpretation. Also, the swing parameters are slightly varied in a smooth, continuous manner. According to the results of the timing measurements presented in this paper, the amount of binary swing for sequences is increased.
